profile_data.summary:
► My expertise lies in the design, prototyping, and testing of Power Electronics circuits; among my specialities are:
•	High Power/Frequency Converters – AC/DC, DC/AC, DC/DC, Resonant, and Multilevel Power Supply Design
•	Magnetics Design – Modelling/Predicting/Measuring of Magnetic Components' Core and Winding Losses
•	Wireless Power Transfer (WPT) and Inductive Power Transfer (IPT) for Electric Vehicles (EVs)
•	Electrical Characterization and Modelling of Power Semiconductor Devices
•	Finite Element Analysis (FEA) and Thermal Analysis – ANSYS Maxwell/Q3D/Icepak/Simplorer
•	Engineering Software: MATLAB Coding/Simulink, PLECS, LTSpice, SaberRD, Altium Designer, KiCad, Proteus, AutoCAD
profile_data.headline: Power Electronics Engineer at Amazon Web Services (AWS)

experience.description:
•	Designing of power electronics converters (AC-DC, DC-AC, DC-DC, and PWM/resonant/multilevel converters).
•	Working on Creepage and Clearance (C&C) requirements of Silicon Carbide (SiC) power module for developing the BMW electric vehicle (EV) power converter.
•	Investigating the performance of different power devices, such as SiC MOSFET and SiC JFET, in the boost converter, which includes designing the control system and high-power test rig for 750V DC output voltage and 3.3 kW power for over 98% efficiency.
•	Magnetics designing, including measuring and characterizing the high-frequency transformers and inductors' core loss and winding loss using IWATSU B-H Analyzer SY-8218 and impedance analyzer.
•	Designing and simulating five/two-level neutral point clamped (NPC) dual active bridge (DAB) DC-DC converter (1.2 kV, 100 kW, 50 kHz), with optimizing the capacitor voltage balancing and zero voltage switching conditions.
•	Designing, simulating, and optimizing resonant LLC and four-switch buck-boost DC-DC converters.
•	Conducting a double pulse test (DPT) to characterize the semiconductor devices' switching losses and the parasitic parameters.
•	Electrical characterizing of power MOSFETs using Keysight B1505A power device analyzer.
•	Conducting electromagnetic simulations in ANSYS Q3D to optimize parasitic elements, current distribution, and characterizing the power module.
•	Performing electric circuit simulation in LTSpice and experimental validation to evaluate the integrated Rogowski coil into the half-bridge PCB for the peak current protection with the analogue control design.
•	Designing, simulating, and testing the high/low/band pass filter, integrator circuit, and delta-sigma ADC for the analogue control design of the power converters for peak current protection.
•	Simulating and testing the sensitivity of current transformers (CTs) with different core laminations, number/type of turns, and burden resistors for current detection of the power converters.
experience.title: Power Electronics Engineer

experience.description:
▪ Department of Electronic and Electrical Engineering
▪ The Electrical Energy Management Group (EEMG) undertake research into low-carbon electrical systems that are enabled by advanced, compact and highly efficient electrical machines and power electronic conversion. The group is a core member of the UK Centre for Power Electronics. The research investigates new technologies for the next generation of power electronics, using emerging wide-bandgap power semiconductor devices. (http://www.bristol.ac.uk/engineering/research/em/)

► Projects:
•	Proposing new User-Friendly Loss Maps (Component-based) for standardized magnetic components.
•	Proposing Artificial Neural Network Aided Loss Maps (NNALM) for inductors and HF transformers.
•	Analyzing the core loss of high-frequency transformers under different load conditions using Ansys Maxwell.
•	Designing a new in-situ measurement method of high-frequency winding loss in cored inductors.
•	Designing a new in-situ measurement method of winding loss in cored high-frequency Transformers.
•	Designing a new method for offline compensation of phase discrepancy in measuring the core/winding loss.
•	Working on an analytical method for fast calculation of inductor operating space for high-frequency core loss estimation in two-level and three-level PWM converters.
•	Working on a Triple pulse test (TPT) for characterizing power loss in magnetic components in analogous to a double pulse test (DPT) for power electronics devices.
experience.title: Research Assistant

experience.description:

Providing pro-active support to students, answering questions, solving problems, and helping them to understand. Examining practicals as required or marking worksheets in class or outside with the help of academics.

experience.title: Teaching Assistant

experience.description: Comparing the winding loss and core loss results of commercial inductors predicted by RedExpert, an online tool from Würth, with the empirical measurements obtained from the Triple Pulse Test (TPT) and in-situ large-signal winding loss methods in collaboration with the Würth Elektronik, Frenetic, and University of Bristol.
experience.title: Lead Power Electronics Researcher

education.description:
► Thesis Topic: Prediction and Measurement of High-Frequency Power Losses in Magnetic Components under Power Electronics Excitation.
► Related to this research, 8 journal papers and 3 conference papers have been published.
► Advisers: Prof. Xibo Yuan and Dr. Jun Wang

•	Working on the magnetic components' precise high-frequency core loss and winding loss measurements.
education.activities: Teaching Support Assistant and Research Assistant at the Electrical Energy Management Group (EEMG), Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering (https://www.bristol.ac.uk/engineering/research/em/)

education.description:
► Thesis Topic: Design and Prototyping of a Wireless Power Transfer for Electric Vehicles
► Related to this research, 4 journal papers and 5 conference papers have been published, and 2 patents have been taken out on this project.
► Adviser: Prof. Mojtaba Mirsalim

•	Head of Wireless Power Transfer (WPT) and Inductive Power Transfer (IPT) EMTRL research group.
•	Magnetic design, optimization and prototyping of the Wireless Power Transfer (WPT) for charging electric vehicles with the new integration methods.
•	Designing and prototyping efficient high-frequency full-bridge resonant inverter and full-bridge rectifier.
•	FEA Optimization of wireless charging system using Ansys Maxwell-based electromagnetic FEA analysis, Simplorer-based circuit simulation and MATLAB-based lumped system analysis.
•	Performing electro-thermal analysis of the WPTs' magnetic structures utilizing ANSYS/Maxwell/Fluent/Workbench

honors.description:
• Our Team from the University of Bristol won the 3rd Place Outstanding Performance Award in the MagNet Challenge 2023, organized by Princeton University and Dartmouth College, and sponsored by Google, Enphase Energy and IEEE Power Electronics Society.
• We used an LSTM-based machine learning framework with transfer learning and data augmentation techniques to address the challenge of modelling magnetic core loss under power electronics waveforms to replace the classic Steinmetz Equation.
• MagNet Challenge 2023: https://github.com/minjiechen/magnetchallenge
honors.title: IEEE International Challenge in Design Methods for Power Electronics - MagNet Challenge 2023

projects.description: The purpose of this work is to propose accurate approaches for measuring and predicting the core and winding losses of high-frequency transformers and inductors in power electronics applications. The large-signal procedures and practical efforts for precisely characterizing the magnetic component losses with the square wave excitation are elaborated. The ultimate objective is to improve loss measurement methods and predictions to enable a quick and accurate estimation, which is beneficial for both commercial magnetic component manufacturers and end-users.
projects.title: Prediction and Measurement of High-Frequency Power Losses in Magnetic Components under Power Electronics Excitation
